clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Impairment and Imaging Correlates in End Stage Renal Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Cognitive Impairment and Imaging Correlates in End Stage Renal Disease

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to understand cognitive impairment in end stage renal disease before and after a kidney transplant.

detailed_description.textblock: Cognitive impairment is very common in patients with End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD). It exact mechanisms are not clear, but patients with ESRD have more cerebral white matter changes. Several studies have shown that cognitive function improves post-transplant, indicating that there may be some reversibility in the process. This study will examine the correlation between cognitive impairment and structural brain changes before and after renal transplantation. We will also study the correlation of cognitive function with serum inflammatory markers before and after transplant. These results will be compared to aged matched healthy controls without kidney disease.

arm_group.description: ESRD patients awaiting renal transplantation who are expected to get a renal transplant in the next few months

study_pop.textblock: The study population will include patients from the renal transplant waiting list at University of Kansas Medical Center. They will be tested before renal transplant and 3 months after renal transplantation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pre-transplant ESRD patients between the ages of 30 and 70 years who are listed for renal transplantation
- Able to sign pre-transplant consent on their own will
- Have english as their native language
Exclusion Criteria:
- Current use of antipsychotics or anti-epileptics
- Inability to read or write which will limit their ability to perform the cognitive tests
- Claustrophobia or inability to get MRI for other reasons
- Unable to sign consent
